text:
This is the chemical formula for the active
ingredient in a common, over-the-counter nasal
decongestant.

And this is the chemical formula for an extremely
dangerous street drug.

They have the same boiling point, the same
molecular mass, and are made up of the exact
same elements, in almost the exact same structure.

These two chemicals are mirror images known
as enantiomers.

They’re sort of like your left and right
hands - if your right hand was evil.

And for the same reason your right hand only
fits into a right-handed glove and your left

hand only fits into a left-handed glove, each
enantiomer fits only into its corresponding
receptor.

When the receptors for the nasal spray molecules
are activated, they send out a neurotransmission
that helps open the nasal passages.

But when the receptors for the street drug
molecules get filled, the resulting neurotransmissions

cause a spurt of euphoria and aphrodisia in
the near term, and addiction and brain damage
in the long term.

Thousands of other molecules also have left-
and right-handed versions.

Right-handed penicillamine binds to toxic
heavy metals in the bloodstream and lets you
pee them out.

On the other hand, left-handed penicillamine
is incredibly toxic itself since it blocks

the body’s ability to use Vitamin B6 and
causes your brain to malfunction.

Left-handed carvone makes things smell like
mint.

Right-handed carvone makes things smell like
licorice.

Despite mirror molecules’ incredibly similar
structures, you can’t just easily convert
one into the other.

To turn nasal spray into meth, you’d need
to first break its very strong covalent bonds,

and that requires dangerous reagents and expensive,
high-pressure lab equipment.

But the dark corners of the internet are filled
with descriptions of people trying - and miserably

failing - to get meth - and its resulting
high - from nasal sprays.

Companies that produce those sprays have even
changed the name of the active ingredient

on the package to try to discourage these
would-be Walter Whites who can’t get their
chemistry ... right.
Hi, it’s Kate!

For a behind the scenes look at how this video
was made, check out the link in the video
description.

And if you're a fan of enantiomers, chemistry,
or science in general and want to stand up

for the future of science, consider taking
to the streets on April 22 at one of the many
Marches for Science around the world.

Or, if you prefer, you can make your voice
heard in other ways.

Whatever you decide to do, we appreciate your
help making the world a welcoming place for
curious people.
